   116	- [ ] T026 [US3] Handle 401/403/500 responses with generic retry messaging in src/controllers/review_invitations_controller.js and src/views/components/error-banner.html
   117	- [ ] T027 [US3] Ensure invitation retrieval proceeds when notification fails in src/services/invitation_creation_service.js (do not block on failure)
   118	- [ ] T028 [US3] Add audit logging for unauthorized access attempts in src/services/security_log_service.js
   119	
   120	**Checkpoint**: All user stories should now be independently functional
   121	
   122	---
   123	
   124	## Phase 6: Polish & Cross-Cutting Concerns
   125	
   126	**Purpose**: Improvements that affect multiple user stories
   127	
   128	- [ ] T029 [P] Add loading/empty state copy in src/views/review-invitations.html and styles in src/views/review-invitations.css
   129	- [ ] T030 [P] Validate and update quickstart steps in specs/001-review-invitation/quickstart.md
   130	- [ ] T031 [P] Add performance note and basic timing log in src/views/scripts/review-invitations.js
   131	- [ ] T032 [P] Verify keyboard-only navigation instructions in specs/001-review-invitation/quickstart.md
   132	
   133	---
   134	
   135	## Dependencies & Execution Order
   136	
   137	### Phase Dependencies
   138	
   139	- **Setup (Phase 1)**: No dependencies - can start immediately
   140	- **Foundational (Phase 2)**: Depends on Setup completion - BLOCKS all user stories
   141	- **User Stories (Phase 3+)**: All depend on Foundational phase completion
   142	- **Polish (Final Phase)**: Depends on all desired user stories being complete
   143	
   144	### User Story Dependencies
   145	
   146	- **User Story 1 (P1)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - No dependencies on other stories
   147	- **User Story 2 (P2)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - Independent of US1 but uses shared foundation
   148	- **User Story 3 (P3)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - Independent of US1/US2 but uses shared foundation
   149	
   150	### Within Each User Story
   151	
   152	- Acceptance tests in `UC-11-AT.md` before implementation
   153	- Models before services
   154	- Services before controllers/views
   155	- Core implementation before integration
   156	
   157	### Parallel Opportunities
   158	
   159	- Phase 1 tasks marked [P]
   160	- Phase 2 tasks marked [P]
   161	- Acceptance test updates per user story
   162	- Model creation within a user story
   163	- Different user stories can run in parallel after Phase 2
   164	
   165	---
   166	
   167	## Parallel Example: User Story 1
   168	
   169	```bash
   170	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 1 first:
   171	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for list fields, ordering, pagination, default pending filter, and action buttons"
   172	
   173	# Launch models for User Story 1 together:
   174	Task: "Create ReviewInvitation model in src/models/review_invitation.js"
   175	Task: "Create Paper model in src/models/paper.js"
   176	```
   177	
   178	---
   179	
   180	## Parallel Example: User Story 2
   181	
   182	```bash
   183	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 2 first:
   184	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for notification delivery and content"
   185	
   186	# Run model and template work together:
   187	Task: "Create Notification model in src/models/notification.js"
   188	Task: "Create notification template content in src/views/templates/review-invitation-notification.txt"
   189	```
   190	
   191	---
   192	
   193	## Parallel Example: User Story 3
   194	
   195	```bash
   196	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 3 first:
   197	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for authorization, notification failure resilience, and generic retry messaging"
   198	
   199	# Parallelize auth + logging:
   200	Task: "Enforce reviewer authorization in src/services/authorization_service.js"
   201	Task: "Add audit logging for unauthorized access attempts in src/services/security_log_service.js"
   202	```
   203	
   204	---
   205	
   206	## Implementation Strategy
   207	
   208	### MVP First (User Story 1 Only)
   209	
   210	1. Complete Phase 1: Setup
   211	2. Complete Phase 2: Foundational (CRITICAL - blocks all stories)
   212	3. Complete Phase 3: User Story 1
   213	4. **STOP and VALIDATE**: Test User Story 1 independently
   214	5. Deploy/demo if ready
   215	
   216	### Incremental Delivery
   217	
   218	1. Complete Setup + Foundational → Foundation ready
   219	2. Add User Story 1 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo (MVP!)
   220	3. Add User Story 2 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   221	4. Add User Story 3 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   222	5. Each story adds value without breaking previous stories
   223	
   224	### Parallel Team Strategy
   225	
   226	With multiple developers:
   227	
   228	1. Team completes Setup + Foundational together
   229	2. Once Foundational is done:
   230	   - Developer A: User Story 1
   231	   - Developer B: User Story 2
   232	   - Developer C: User Story 3
   233	3. Stories complete and integrate independently
   234	
   235	---
   236	
   237	## Notes
   238	
   239	- [P] tasks = different files, no dependencies
   240	- [Story] label maps task to specific user story for traceability
   241	- Each user story should be independently completable and testable
   242	- Verify acceptance criteria are defined before implementing
   243	- Avoid vague tasks and cross-story dependencies

**Identifying spec-plan inconsistencies**

I've found discrepancies between the spec and plan, especially around pagination, keyboard access, and performance, with some features in the plan but missing from the spec. Tasks partially comply with update documentation rules but miss explicit steps for some UC documents, potentially violating the constitution's mandatory update requirements.

**Generating detailed requirements and coverage analysis**

I've mapped each functional and non-functional requirement to tasks, identifying critical constitution violations for missing explicit UC-11.md updates and references, major coverage gaps (like missing tasks for invitation creation), scope conflicts on acceptance handling, and several inconsistencies between spec, plan, and tasks. The analysis includes a proposed categorization of issues, a requirements coverage table, and a plan to report and prioritize these findings.

**Preparing remediation steps without file changes**

I'm outlining recommended actions like adding NFRs via specification tools, manually updating the spec to cover uncovered features, and adding missing UC-11.md update tasks, while emphasizing these require approval before any actual edits since no file modifications will be made now.

## Specification Analysis Report

| ID | Category | Severity | Location(s) | Summary | Recommendation |
|----|----------|----------|-------------|---------|----------------|

- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:

  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /root/493-lab/Lab2/specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md
@@
 ## Clarifications
 
 ### Session 2026-02-02
@@
 - Q: Is login required to view the invitations list? → A: Yes, login required.
 
+## Scope Clarifications
+
+- Accept/Reject processing logic is out of scope for UC-11; UI may show options but no state change is required in this feature.
+- Invitation detail view and abstract visibility after acceptance are handled in a separate use case; UC-11 only covers the invitations list view.
+- Invitation list ordering (newest first) and pagination (beyond 20 items) are required in this feature.
+- Keyboard-only navigation support is required for the invitations list view.
+
 ## Use Case Mapping *(mandatory)*
@@
 ## Requirements *(mandatory)*
 
 ### Functional Requirements
 
 - **FR-001**: System MUST create a review invitation when an editor assigns a reviewer to a paper.
 - **FR-002**: System MUST display pending review invitations to the invited reviewer with paper title and invitation status.
 - **FR-003**: System MUST provide Accept and Reject options for each pending invitation.
 - **FR-004**: System MUST attempt to send a review invitation notification to the reviewer when an invitation is created.
 - **FR-005**: System MUST keep the invitation available in the CMS even if notification delivery fails.
 - **FR-006**: System MUST restrict invitation visibility to the invited reviewer.
 - **FR-007**: System MUST automatically mark an invitation as declined when the review due date passes without a response.
 - **FR-008**: System MUST show a generic, user-friendly error message with retry guidance when invitations cannot be retrieved.
 - **FR-009**: System MUST allow reviewers with multiple invitations to view each invitation as a distinct item linked to the correct paper.
-- **FR-010**: System MUST limit invitation list details to paper title prior to acceptance; abstract becomes visible after acceptance.
+- **FR-010**: System MUST limit invitation list details to paper title prior to acceptance.
 - **FR-011**: System MUST show only pending invitations by default and allow filtering to view non-pending invitations.
 - **FR-012**: System MUST require the reviewer to be logged in to view invitations.
+- **FR-013**: System MUST order invitations newest first and support pagination beyond 20 items.
+- **FR-014**: System MUST include paper title and response due date in invitation notifications.
 
 ### Assumptions
@@
 ### Key Entities *(include if feature involves data)*
@@
 - **Notification**: The outbound message informing a reviewer about a new invitation and its delivery status.
 
+### Non-Functional Requirements
+
+- **NFR-001**: Invitation list loads within 2 seconds under normal load.
+- **NFR-002**: Invitations are visible to the invited reviewer within 1 minute of assignment.
+- **NFR-003**: Invitations list is keyboard accessible (tab order, focus states, and actionable controls usable without a mouse).
+
 ## Success Criteria *(mandatory)*
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Clarifying accept/reject scope and updating tasks**

I'm updating the spec to include accept/reject handling within scope, clarifying that abstract visibility after acceptance remains excluded per prior decisions. Tasks will reflect processing accept/reject actions in the controller/service and UI, noting the lack of explicit API endpoints or contract updates while considering acceptance test additions.

**Expanding spec and tasks with accept/reject actions**

I'm adding scope clarifications and new functional requirements to include accept/reject status processing and persistence. Tasks will be updated to insert accept/reject endpoints in the OpenAPI contract, implement service and controller logic, wire UI actions, and renumber all affected tasks for consistency across phases.

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /root/493-lab/Lab2/specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md
@@
 ## Scope Clarifications
 
-- Accept/Reject processing logic is out of scope for UC-11; UI may show options but no state change is required in this feature.
+- Accept/Reject processing logic is in scope for UC-11; selecting either updates the invitation status.
 - Invitation detail view and abstract visibility after acceptance are handled in a separate use case; UC-11 only covers the invitations list view.
 - Invitation list ordering (newest first) and pagination (beyond 20 items) are required in this feature.
 - Keyboard-only navigation support is required for the invitations list view.
@@
 - **FR-002**: System MUST display pending review invitations to the invited reviewer with paper title and invitation status.
-- **FR-003**: System MUST provide Accept and Reject options for each pending invitation.
+- **FR-003**: System MUST provide Accept and Reject options for each pending invitation and persist the reviewer decision.
@@
 - **FR-012**: System MUST require the reviewer to be logged in to view invitations.
 - **FR-013**: System MUST order invitations newest first and support pagination beyond 20 items.
 - **FR-014**: System MUST include paper title and response due date in invitation notifications.
*** End Patch

  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

Updated scope and requirements to put Accept/Reject processing in scope, and adjusted tasks to implement it (including contract update and action handlers).

Changes applied
- `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md`: Accept/Reject now in scope; FR-003 updated to require persistence of decisions.

If you want, I can rerun the analysis pass to confirm alignment.

## User Input

```text

```

You **MUST** consider the user input before proceeding (if not empty).

## Goal

Identify inconsistencies, duplications, ambiguities, and underspecified items across the three core artifacts (`spec.md`, `plan.md`, `tasks.md`) before implementation. This command MUST run only after `/speckit.tasks` has successfully produced a complete `tasks.md`.

## Operating Constraints

**STRICTLY READ-ONLY**: Do **not** modify any files. Output a structured analysis report. Offer an optional remediation plan (user must explicitly approve before any follow-up editing commands would be invoked manually).

**Constitution Authority**: The project constitution (`.specify/memory/constitution.md`) is **non-negotiable** within this analysis scope. Constitution conflicts are automatically CRITICAL and require adjustment of the spec, plan, or tasks—not dilution, reinterpretation, or silent ignoring of the principle. If a principle itself needs to change, that must occur in a separate, explicit constitution update outside `/speckit.analyze`.

## Execution Steps

### 1. Initialize Analysis Context

Run `.specify/scripts/bash/check-prerequisites.sh --json --require-tasks --include-tasks` once from repo root and parse JSON for FEATURE_DIR and AVAILABLE_DOCS. Derive absolute paths:

- SPEC = FEATURE_DIR/spec.md
- PLAN = FEATURE_DIR/plan.md
- TASKS = FEATURE_DIR/tasks.md

Abort with an error message if any required file is missing (instruct the user to run missing prerequisite command).
For single quotes in args like "I'm Groot", use escape syntax: e.g 'I'\''m Groot' (or double-quote if possible: "I'm Groot").

### 2. Load Artifacts (Progressive Disclosure)

Load only the minimal necessary context from each artifact:

**From spec.md:**

- Overview/Context
- Functional Requirements
- Non-Functional Requirements
- User Stories
- Edge Cases (if present)

**From plan.md:**

- Architecture/stack choices
- Data Model references
- Phases
- Technical constraints

**From tasks.md:**

- Task IDs
- Descriptions
- Phase grouping
- Parallel markers [P]
- Referenced file paths

**From constitution:**

- Load `.specify/memory/constitution.md` for principle validation

### 3. Build Semantic Models

Create internal representations (do not include raw artifacts in output):

- **Requirements inventory**: Each functional + non-functional requirement with a stable key (derive slug based on imperative phrase; e.g., "User can upload file" → `user-can-upload-file`)
- **User story/action inventory**: Discrete user actions with acceptance criteria
- **Task coverage mapping**: Map each task to one or more requirements or stories (inference by keyword / explicit reference patterns like IDs or key phrases)
- **Constitution rule set**: Extract principle names and MUST/SHOULD normative statements

### 4. Detection Passes (Token-Efficient Analysis)

Focus on high-signal findings. Limit to 50 findings total; aggregate remainder in overflow summary.

#### A. Duplication Detection

- Identify near-duplicate requirements
- Mark lower-quality phrasing for consolidation

#### B. Ambiguity Detection

- Flag vague adjectives (fast, scalable, secure, intuitive, robust) lacking measurable criteria
- Flag unresolved placeholders (TODO, TKTK, ???, `<placeholder>`, etc.)

#### C. Underspecification

- Requirements with verbs but missing object or measurable outcome
- User stories missing acceptance criteria alignment
- Tasks referencing files or components not defined in spec/plan

#### D. Constitution Alignment

- Any requirement or plan element conflicting with a MUST principle
- Missing mandated sections or quality gates from constitution

#### E. Coverage Gaps

- Requirements with zero associated tasks
- Tasks with no mapped requirement/story
- Non-functional requirements not reflected in tasks (e.g., performance, security)

#### F. Inconsistency

- Terminology drift (same concept named differently across files)
- Data entities referenced in plan but absent in spec (or vice versa)
- Task ordering contradictions (e.g., integration tasks before foundational setup tasks without dependency note)
- Conflicting requirements (e.g., one requires Next.js while other specifies Vue)

### 5. Severity Assignment

Use this heuristic to prioritize findings:

- **CRITICAL**: Violates constitution MUST, missing core spec artifact, or requirement with zero coverage that blocks baseline functionality
- **HIGH**: Duplicate or conflicting requirement, ambiguous security/performance attribute, untestable acceptance criterion
- **MEDIUM**: Terminology drift, missing non-functional task coverage, underspecified edge case
- **LOW**: Style/wording improvements, minor redundancy not affecting execution order

### 6. Produce Compact Analysis Report

Output a Markdown report (no file writes) with the following structure:

## Specification Analysis Report

| ID | Category | Severity | Location(s) | Summary | Recommendation |
|----|----------|----------|-------------|---------|----------------|
| A1 | Duplication | HIGH | spec.md:L120-134 | Two similar requirements ... | Merge phrasing; keep clearer version |

(Add one row per finding; generate stable IDs prefixed by category initial.)

**Coverage Summary Table:**

| Requirement Key | Has Task? | Task IDs | Notes |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|-------|

**Constitution Alignment Issues:** (if any)

**Unmapped Tasks:** (if any)

**Metrics:**

- Total Requirements
- Total Tasks
- Coverage % (requirements with >=1 task)
- Ambiguity Count
- Duplication Count
- Critical Issues Count

### 7. Provide Next Actions

At end of report, output a concise Next Actions block:

- If CRITICAL issues exist: Recommend resolving before `/speckit.implement`
- If only LOW/MEDIUM: User may proceed, but provide improvement suggestions
- Provide explicit command suggestions: e.g., "Run /speckit.specify with refinement", "Run /speckit.plan to adjust architecture", "Manually edit tasks.md to add coverage for 'performance-metrics'"

### 8. Offer Remediation

Ask the user: "Would you like me to suggest concrete remediation edits for the top N issues?" (Do NOT apply them automatically.)

## Operating Principles

### Context Efficiency

- **Minimal high-signal tokens**: Focus on actionable findings, not exhaustive documentation
- **Progressive disclosure**: Load artifacts incrementally; don't dump all content into analysis
- **Token-efficient output**: Limit findings table to 50 rows; summarize overflow
- **Deterministic results**: Rerunning without changes should produce consistent IDs and counts

### Analysis Guidelines

- **NEVER modify files** (this is read-only analysis)
- **NEVER hallucinate missing sections** (if absent, report them accurately)
- **Prioritize constitution violations** (these are always CRITICAL)
- **Use examples over exhaustive rules** (cite specific instances, not generic patterns)
- **Report zero issues gracefully** (emit success report with coverage statistics)

## Context

# Lab2 CMS Constitution

## Core Principles

### I. Use-Case Traceability (NON-NEGOTIABLE)
Every feature or change MUST map to a specific use case file `UC-XX.md`. If a new
use case is introduced, a new `UC-XX.md` MUST be added and referenced in specs,
plans, and tasks. No implementation is accepted without explicit use-case linkage.

### II. Acceptance Tests as Contract
Acceptance tests are the source of truth and live in `UC-XX-AT.md` files paired
with their use cases. Updates to behavior MUST update the corresponding
acceptance test document before or alongside implementation, and a feature is
only complete when its acceptance criteria are demonstrably satisfied.

### III. MVC Separation
The CMS MUST follow MVC architecture. Models encapsulate data and domain rules,
controllers coordinate user interactions and application flow, and views render
presentation only. Business logic in views is prohibited.

### IV. Vanilla Web Stack Only
Implementation MUST use vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Frameworks, UI
libraries, and build-tool-dependent abstractions are not allowed unless the
constitution is amended to permit them.

### V. Simplicity & Clarity
Prefer the simplest structure that satisfies the use case and acceptance tests.
Avoid unnecessary abstractions or premature generalization; clarity and
readability take precedence over cleverness.

## Project Constraints

- Use cases are stored in `UC-XX.md` and acceptance tests in `UC-XX-AT.md`.
- Any new use case MUST follow the next sequential `UC-XX` identifier and include
  a matching acceptance test file.
- All project documentation (specs, plans, tasks) MUST reference the relevant
  `UC-XX` identifiers for traceability.

## Development Workflow & Quality Gates

- Every plan and spec MUST include a constitution check validating: use-case
  traceability, acceptance test coverage, MVC separation, and vanilla stack
  compliance.
- Tasks MUST include explicit steps to update/add `UC-XX.md` and `UC-XX-AT.md`
  when behavior changes or new functionality is introduced.
- Reviews MUST verify that acceptance tests reflect the intended behavior and
  that implementation aligns with the mapped use cases.

## Governance

- This constitution supersedes all other project guidance.
- Amendments require documentation of the rationale, scope, and migration plan
  (if behavior changes or breaking constraints are introduced).
- Semantic versioning applies: MAJOR for breaking governance changes, MINOR for
  new/expanded principles or sections, PATCH for clarifications and wording.
- Compliance is reviewed during planning and before acceptance of changes.

**Version**: 1.0.0 | **Ratified**: 2026-01-31 | **Last Amended**: 2026-01-31

    18	- Q: Is login required to view the invitations list? → A: Yes, login required.
    19	
    20	## Scope Clarifications
    21	
    22	- Accept/Reject processing logic is in scope for UC-11; selecting either updates the invitation status.
    23	- Invitation detail view and abstract visibility after acceptance are handled in a separate use case; UC-11 only covers the invitations list view.
    24	- Invitation list ordering (newest first) and pagination (beyond 20 items) are required in this feature.
    25	- Keyboard-only navigation support is required for the invitations list view.
    26	
    27	## Use Case Mapping *(mandatory)*
    28	
    29	- **Primary Use Case(s)**: UC-11
    30	- **Acceptance Tests**: UC-11-AT
    31	- **Notes**: Specifies behavior for receiving and viewing review invitations for assigned papers.
    32	
    33	### User Story 1 - View Pending Review Invitation (Priority: P1)
    34	
    35	As a reviewer, I want to see my pending review invitations so I can decide whether to accept or reject each assignment.
    36	
    37	**Why this priority**: This is the core value of the feature; without it, reviewers cannot respond to review requests.
    38	
    39	**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by assigning a reviewer to a paper and confirming the invitation appears with Accept/Reject options.
    40	
    41	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    42	
    43	1. **Given** a reviewer is assigned to a paper, **When** the reviewer views their invitations list, **Then** the pending invitation appears with paper title and Accept/Reject options.
    44	2. **Given** a reviewer has multiple pending invitations, **When** they view the invitations list, **Then** each invitation is listed and correctly associated with its paper.
    45	
    46	---
    47	
    48	### User Story 2 - Receive Invitation Notification (Priority: P2)
    49	
    50	As a reviewer, I want to be notified when I receive a new review invitation so I don’t miss review requests.
    51	
    52	**Why this priority**: Notifications reduce missed assignments and improve response time.
    53	
    54	**Independent Test**: Can be tested by creating an invitation and verifying a notification is sent to the reviewer’s registered contact method.
    55	
    56	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    57	
    58	1. **Given** a reviewer is assigned to a paper and notification service is available, **When** the invitation is created, **Then** the reviewer receives a notification of the invitation.
    59	
    60	---
    61	
    62	### User Story 3 - Secure and Resilient Access (Priority: P3)
    63	
    64	As a reviewer, I want my invitations to remain accessible even if notifications fail, and I expect only invited reviewers to see each invitation.
    65	
    66	**Why this priority**: Ensures reliability and protects confidentiality of submissions.
    67	
    68	**Independent Test**: Can be tested by simulating notification failure, delayed login, and unauthorized access attempts while verifying correct visibility and messaging.
    69	
    70	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    71	
    72	1. **Given** a notification failure occurs, **When** the reviewer later views their invitations, **Then** the invitation is still visible and actionable.
    73	2. **Given** a reviewer who is not invited to a paper, **When** they attempt to access that invitation, **Then** access is denied or the invitation is not shown.
    74	3. **Given** an invitation retrieval error occurs, **When** the reviewer views invitations, **Then** a generic error message with retry guidance is shown.
    75	
    76	---
    77	
    78	### Edge Cases
    79	
    80	- Reviewer does not log in until days after the invitation is created.
    81	- Notification delivery fails but the invitation still exists.
    82	- Multiple invitations for different papers must be distinguishable.
    83	- A system error prevents invitations from loading.
    84	- A reviewer attempts to access an invitation they were not assigned.
    85	- Review due date passes before response.
    86	
    87	## Requirements *(mandatory)*
    88	
    89	### Functional Requirements
    90	
    91	- **FR-001**: System MUST create a review invitation when an editor assigns a reviewer to a paper.
    92	- **FR-002**: System MUST display pending review invitations to the invited reviewer with paper title and invitation status.
    93	- **FR-003**: System MUST provide Accept and Reject options for each pending invitation and persist the reviewer decision.
    94	- **FR-004**: System MUST attempt to send a review invitation notification to the reviewer when an invitation is created.
    95	- **FR-005**: System MUST keep the invitation available in the CMS even if notification delivery fails.
    96	- **FR-006**: System MUST restrict invitation visibility to the invited reviewer.
    97	- **FR-007**: System MUST automatically mark an invitation as declined when the review due date passes without a response.
    98	- **FR-008**: System MUST show a generic, user-friendly error message with retry guidance when invitations cannot be retrieved.
    99	- **FR-009**: System MUST allow reviewers with multiple invitations to view each invitation as a distinct item linked to the correct paper.
   100	- **FR-010**: System MUST limit invitation list details to paper title prior to acceptance.
   101	- **FR-011**: System MUST show only pending invitations by default and allow filtering to view non-pending invitations.
   102	- **FR-012**: System MUST require the reviewer to be logged in to view invitations.
   103	- **FR-013**: System MUST order invitations newest first and support pagination beyond 20 items.
   104	- **FR-014**: System MUST include paper title and response due date in invitation notifications.
   105	
   106	### Assumptions
   107	
   108	- The reviewer’s registered contact method is used for invitation notifications.
   109	
   110	### Key Entities *(include if feature involves data)*
   111	
   112	- **Review Invitation**: Represents a request to review a paper; includes status (pending/accepted/rejected/declined/expired), created date, and response deadline.
   113	- **Reviewer**: Registered user who can view and respond to invitations; includes contact information.
   114	- **Paper**: The submission being reviewed; includes identifier, title, and abstract.
   115	- **Notification**: The outbound message informing a reviewer about a new invitation and its delivery status.
   116	
   117	### Non-Functional Requirements
   118	
   119	- **NFR-001**: Invitation list loads within 2 seconds under normal load.
   120	- **NFR-002**: Invitations are visible to the invited reviewer within 1 minute of assignment.
   121	- **NFR-003**: Invitations list is keyboard accessible (tab order, focus states, and actionable controls usable without a mouse).
   122	
   123	## Success Criteria *(mandatory)*
   124	
   125	### Measurable Outcomes
   126	
   127	- **SC-001**: 95% of reviewers can locate a pending invitation within 2 minutes of logging in during usability testing.
   128	- **SC-002**: 99% of invitations are visible to the invited reviewer within 1 minute of assignment in controlled tests.
   129	- **SC-003**: 98% of invitation notifications are delivered successfully when the notification service is available.
   130	- **SC-004**: 100% of access attempts by non-invited reviewers are blocked in authorization tests.
   131	- **SC-005**: 100% of invitation retrieval failures display a generic message with retry guidance in testing.

(file: /root/493-lab/Lab2/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)

- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.

  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

   165	- Acceptance test updates per user story
   166	- Model creation within a user story
   167	- Different user stories can run in parallel after Phase 2
   168	
   169	---
   170	
   171	## Parallel Example: User Story 1
   172	
   173	```bash
   174	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 1 first:
   175	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for list fields, ordering, pagination, default pending filter, and action buttons"
   176	
   177	# Launch models for User Story 1 together:
   178	Task: "Create ReviewInvitation model in src/models/review_invitation.js"
   179	Task: "Create Paper model in src/models/paper.js"
   180	```
   181	
   182	---
   183	
   184	## Parallel Example: User Story 2
   185	
   186	```bash
   187	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 2 first:
   188	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for notification delivery and content"
   189	
   190	# Run model and template work together:
   191	Task: "Create Notification model in src/models/notification.js"
   192	Task: "Create notification template content in src/views/templates/review-invitation-notification.txt"
   193	```
   194	
   195	---
   196	
   197	## Parallel Example: User Story 3
   198	
   199	```bash
   200	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 3 first:
   201	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for authorization, notification failure resilience, and generic retry messaging"
   202	
   203	# Parallelize auth + logging:
   204	Task: "Enforce reviewer authorization in src/services/authorization_service.js"
   205	Task: "Add audit logging for unauthorized access attempts in src/services/security_log_service.js"
   206	```
   207	
   208	---
   209	
   210	## Implementation Strategy
   211	
   212	### MVP First (User Story 1 Only)
   213	
   214	1. Complete Phase 1: Setup
   215	2. Complete Phase 2: Foundational (CRITICAL - blocks all stories)
   216	3. Complete Phase 3: User Story 1
   217	4. **STOP and VALIDATE**: Test User Story 1 independently
   218	5. Deploy/demo if ready
   219	
   220	### Incremental Delivery
   221	
   222	1. Complete Setup + Foundational → Foundation ready
   223	2. Add User Story 1 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo (MVP!)
   224	3. Add User Story 2 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   225	4. Add User Story 3 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   226	5. Each story adds value without breaking previous stories
   227	
   228	### Parallel Team Strategy
   229	
   230	With multiple developers:
   231	
   232	1. Team completes Setup + Foundational together
   233	2. Once Foundational is done:
   234	   - Developer A: User Story 1
   235	   - Developer B: User Story 2
   236	   - Developer C: User Story 3
   237	3. Stories complete and integrate independently
   238	
   239	---
   240	
   241	## Notes
   242	
   243	- [P] tasks = different files, no dependencies
   244	- [Story] label maps task to specific user story for traceability
   245	- Each user story should be independently completable and testable
   246	- Verify acceptance criteria are defined before implementing
   247	- Avoid vague tasks and cross-story dependencies

**Identifying spec inconsistencies and coverage gaps**

The plan misses accept/reject actions in scope and lacks endpoints for them despite tasks updating contracts, marking a critical inconsistency needing plan adjustment. Coverage mostly aligns with tasks except a likely partial or ambiguous performance requirement (NFR-001) coverage.

**Flagging critical constitution absence and plan/spec inconsistencies**

The spec critically lacks the required constitution check section, violating constitution rules. Multiple medium-severity underspec and inconsistency issues include unclear auto-decline triggers, partial NFR-001 coverage, accept/reject actions missing from plan scope, and a due date display discrepancy between plan/tasks and spec. Unmapped setup tasks exist but are noted separately. Next steps prioritize fixing the constitution omission and aligning plan scope with spec and tasks.

payload.message:
## Specification Analysis Report

| ID | Category | Severity | Location(s) | Summary | Recommendation |
|----|----------|----------|-------------|---------|----------------|
| C1 | Constitution | CRITICAL | `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md:1-131`, `.specify/memory/constitution.md:41-47` | Spec lacks a constitution check section validating use-case traceability, acceptance tests, MVC separation, and vanilla stack compliance. | Add a constitution check section to `spec.md` mirroring plan’s gate items. |
| I1 | Inconsistency | HIGH | `specs/001-review-invitation/plan.md:8,19`, `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md:20-104`, `specs/001-review-invitation/tasks.md:70-78` | Plan states Accept/Reject processing is out of scope, while spec/tasks include in-scope accept/reject state changes. | Update plan to reflect in-scope accept/reject processing or adjust spec/tasks if out of scope. |
| I2 | Inconsistency | MEDIUM | `specs/001-review-invitation/plan.md:72-76`, `specs/001-review-invitation/tasks.md:70` | Plan only mentions list retrieval contract, but tasks add accept/reject action endpoint to OpenAPI. | Update plan Phase 1 contract scope to include accept/reject action endpoint. |
| I3 | Inconsistency | MEDIUM | `specs/001-review-invitation/plan.md:8`, `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md:91-104`, `specs/001-review-invitation/tasks.md:77-79` | Plan/tasks include showing response due date in list, but spec does not require due date display. | Add an explicit FR for due date display or remove due date from plan/tasks. |
| U1 | Underspecification | MEDIUM | `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md:97`, `specs/001-review-invitation/tasks.md:51` | Auto-decline behavior lacks a trigger definition (background job vs. on-read recalculation). | Specify trigger mechanism in spec and add a task if a scheduler/background job is required. |
| G1 | Coverage Gap | MEDIUM | `specs/001-review-invitation/spec.md:119`, `specs/001-review-invitation/tasks.md:134-135` | NFR-001 (2-second load) only has a logging task; no task ensures or validates performance. | Add a task to implement perf optimization or acceptance criteria verification. |

**Coverage Summary Table:**

| Requirement Key | Has Task? | Task IDs | Notes |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|-------|
| create-review-invitation-on-assignment | Yes | T008 | — |
| display-pending-invitations-with-title-status | Yes | T015, T016, T019, T020 | — |
| provide-accept-reject-and-persist-decision | Yes | T017, T018, T020 | — |
| attempt-notification-on-creation | Yes | T025, T026 | — |
| keep-invitation-available-on-notification-failure | Yes | T032 | — |
| restrict-visibility-to-invited-reviewer | Yes | T005, T030 | — |
| auto-decline-after-response-due | Yes | T009 | Trigger mechanism not specified. |
| show-generic-retry-error-on-retrieval-failure | Yes | T010, T031, T020 | — |
| list-multiple-invitations-distinct | Yes | T019, T020 | — |
| limit-list-details-to-title-pre-acceptance | Yes | T019 | — |
| default-pending-filter-allow-nonpending | Yes | T015, T019, T020 | — |
| require-login-to-view | Yes | T005 | — |
| order-newest-first-and-paginate | Yes | T015, T019, T020 | — |
| include-title-and-due-date-in-notification | Yes | T027, T028 | — |
| nfr-loads-within-2-seconds | Partial | T035 | Logging only. |
| nfr-visible-within-1-minute | Yes | T020 | Auto-refresh intended. |
| nfr-keyboard-accessible | Yes | T011, T021, T019 | Coverage depends on acceptance test detail. |

**Constitution Alignment Issues:**
- C1: Missing constitution check section in `spec.md`.

**Unmapped Tasks:**
- T001, T003, T004 (setup scaffolding tasks).
- T002 (UC-11 documentation update task; governance-driven, not a requirement).
- T034, T036 (polish/quickstart tasks not tied to specific requirements).

**Metrics:**
- Total Requirements: 17
- Total Tasks: 36
- Coverage % (requirements with >=1 task): 100% (17/17)
- Ambiguity Count: 0
- Duplication Count: 0
- Critical Issues Count: 1

## Next Actions
- CRITICAL issue present: resolve before `/speckit.implement`.
- Suggested actions:
  1) Add constitution check section to `spec.md`.
  2) Update `plan.md` to reflect accept/reject in scope and contract updates.
  3) Decide whether due date display is a requirement and align spec/plan/tasks.
  4) Clarify auto-decline trigger and add a task if needed.
  5) Add a performance verification/optimization task for the 2-second NFR.

Would you like me to suggest concrete remediation edits for the top 3 issues?

(file: /root/493-lab/Lab2/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)

Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /root/493-lab/Lab2/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

If you want, I can rerun the analysis pass to confirm remaining issues.

## User Input

```text

```

You **MUST** consider the user input before proceeding (if not empty).

## Goal

Identify inconsistencies, duplications, ambiguities, and underspecified items across the three core artifacts (`spec.md`, `plan.md`, `tasks.md`) before implementation. This command MUST run only after `/speckit.tasks` has successfully produced a complete `tasks.md`.

## Operating Constraints

**STRICTLY READ-ONLY**: Do **not** modify any files. Output a structured analysis report. Offer an optional remediation plan (user must explicitly approve before any follow-up editing commands would be invoked manually).

**Constitution Authority**: The project constitution (`.specify/memory/constitution.md`) is **non-negotiable** within this analysis scope. Constitution conflicts are automatically CRITICAL and require adjustment of the spec, plan, or tasks—not dilution, reinterpretation, or silent ignoring of the principle. If a principle itself needs to change, that must occur in a separate, explicit constitution update outside `/speckit.analyze`.

## Execution Steps

### 1. Initialize Analysis Context

Run `.specify/scripts/bash/check-prerequisites.sh --json --require-tasks --include-tasks` once from repo root and parse JSON for FEATURE_DIR and AVAILABLE_DOCS. Derive absolute paths:

- SPEC = FEATURE_DIR/spec.md
- PLAN = FEATURE_DIR/plan.md
- TASKS = FEATURE_DIR/tasks.md

Abort with an error message if any required file is missing (instruct the user to run missing prerequisite command).
For single quotes in args like "I'm Groot", use escape syntax: e.g 'I'\''m Groot' (or double-quote if possible: "I'm Groot").

### 2. Load Artifacts (Progressive Disclosure)

Load only the minimal necessary context from each artifact:

**From spec.md:**

- Overview/Context
- Functional Requirements
- Non-Functional Requirements
- User Stories
- Edge Cases (if present)

**From plan.md:**

- Architecture/stack choices
- Data Model references
- Phases
- Technical constraints

**From tasks.md:**

- Task IDs
- Descriptions
- Phase grouping
- Parallel markers [P]
- Referenced file paths

**From constitution:**

- Load `.specify/memory/constitution.md` for principle validation

### 3. Build Semantic Models

Create internal representations (do not include raw artifacts in output):

- **Requirements inventory**: Each functional + non-functional requirement with a stable key (derive slug based on imperative phrase; e.g., "User can upload file" → `user-can-upload-file`)
- **User story/action inventory**: Discrete user actions with acceptance criteria
- **Task coverage mapping**: Map each task to one or more requirements or stories (inference by keyword / explicit reference patterns like IDs or key phrases)
- **Constitution rule set**: Extract principle names and MUST/SHOULD normative statements

### 4. Detection Passes (Token-Efficient Analysis)

Focus on high-signal findings. Limit to 50 findings total; aggregate remainder in overflow summary.

#### A. Duplication Detection

- Identify near-duplicate requirements
- Mark lower-quality phrasing for consolidation

#### B. Ambiguity Detection

- Flag vague adjectives (fast, scalable, secure, intuitive, robust) lacking measurable criteria
- Flag unresolved placeholders (TODO, TKTK, ???, `<placeholder>`, etc.)

#### C. Underspecification

- Requirements with verbs but missing object or measurable outcome
- User stories missing acceptance criteria alignment
- Tasks referencing files or components not defined in spec/plan

#### D. Constitution Alignment

- Any requirement or plan element conflicting with a MUST principle
- Missing mandated sections or quality gates from constitution

#### E. Coverage Gaps

- Requirements with zero associated tasks
- Tasks with no mapped requirement/story
- Non-functional requirements not reflected in tasks (e.g., performance, security)

#### F. Inconsistency

- Terminology drift (same concept named differently across files)
- Data entities referenced in plan but absent in spec (or vice versa)
- Task ordering contradictions (e.g., integration tasks before foundational setup tasks without dependency note)
- Conflicting requirements (e.g., one requires Next.js while other specifies Vue)

### 5. Severity Assignment

Use this heuristic to prioritize findings:

- **CRITICAL**: Violates constitution MUST, missing core spec artifact, or requirement with zero coverage that blocks baseline functionality
- **HIGH**: Duplicate or conflicting requirement, ambiguous security/performance attribute, untestable acceptance criterion
- **MEDIUM**: Terminology drift, missing non-functional task coverage, underspecified edge case
- **LOW**: Style/wording improvements, minor redundancy not affecting execution order

### 6. Produce Compact Analysis Report

Output a Markdown report (no file writes) with the following structure:

## Specification Analysis Report

| ID | Category | Severity | Location(s) | Summary | Recommendation |
|----|----------|----------|-------------|---------|----------------|
| A1 | Duplication | HIGH | spec.md:L120-134 | Two similar requirements ... | Merge phrasing; keep clearer version |

(Add one row per finding; generate stable IDs prefixed by category initial.)

**Coverage Summary Table:**

| Requirement Key | Has Task? | Task IDs | Notes |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|-------|

**Constitution Alignment Issues:** (if any)

**Unmapped Tasks:** (if any)

**Metrics:**

- Total Requirements
- Total Tasks
- Coverage % (requirements with >=1 task)
- Ambiguity Count
- Duplication Count
- Critical Issues Count

### 7. Provide Next Actions

At end of report, output a concise Next Actions block:

- If CRITICAL issues exist: Recommend resolving before `/speckit.implement`
- If only LOW/MEDIUM: User may proceed, but provide improvement suggestions
- Provide explicit command suggestions: e.g., "Run /speckit.specify with refinement", "Run /speckit.plan to adjust architecture", "Manually edit tasks.md to add coverage for 'performance-metrics'"

### 8. Offer Remediation

Ask the user: "Would you like me to suggest concrete remediation edits for the top N issues?" (Do NOT apply them automatically.)

## Operating Principles

### Context Efficiency

- **Minimal high-signal tokens**: Focus on actionable findings, not exhaustive documentation
- **Progressive disclosure**: Load artifacts incrementally; don't dump all content into analysis
- **Token-efficient output**: Limit findings table to 50 rows; summarize overflow
- **Deterministic results**: Rerunning without changes should produce consistent IDs and counts

### Analysis Guidelines

- **NEVER modify files** (this is read-only analysis)
- **NEVER hallucinate missing sections** (if absent, report them accurately)
- **Prioritize constitution violations** (these are always CRITICAL)
- **Use examples over exhaustive rules** (cite specific instances, not generic patterns)
- **Report zero issues gracefully** (emit success report with coverage statistics)

- Follow-up TODOs: None

# Lab2 CMS Constitution

## Core Principles

### I. Use-Case Traceability (NON-NEGOTIABLE)
Every feature or change MUST map to a specific use case file `UC-XX.md`. If a new
use case is introduced, a new `UC-XX.md` MUST be added and referenced in specs,
plans, and tasks. No implementation is accepted without explicit use-case linkage.

### II. Acceptance Tests as Contract
Acceptance tests are the source of truth and live in `UC-XX-AT.md` files paired
with their use cases. Updates to behavior MUST update the corresponding
acceptance test document before or alongside implementation, and a feature is
only complete when its acceptance criteria are demonstrably satisfied.

### III. MVC Separation
The CMS MUST follow MVC architecture. Models encapsulate data and domain rules,
controllers coordinate user interactions and application flow, and views render
presentation only. Business logic in views is prohibited.

### IV. Vanilla Web Stack Only
Implementation MUST use vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Frameworks, UI
libraries, and build-tool-dependent abstractions are not allowed unless the
constitution is amended to permit them.

### V. Simplicity & Clarity
Prefer the simplest structure that satisfies the use case and acceptance tests.
Avoid unnecessary abstractions or premature generalization; clarity and
readability take precedence over cleverness.

## Project Constraints

- Use cases are stored in `UC-XX.md` and acceptance tests in `UC-XX-AT.md`.
- Any new use case MUST follow the next sequential `UC-XX` identifier and include
  a matching acceptance test file.
- All project documentation (specs, plans, tasks) MUST reference the relevant
  `UC-XX` identifiers for traceability.

## Development Workflow & Quality Gates

- Every plan and spec MUST include a constitution check validating: use-case
  traceability, acceptance test coverage, MVC separation, and vanilla stack
  compliance.
- Tasks MUST include explicit steps to update/add `UC-XX.md` and `UC-XX-AT.md`
  when behavior changes or new functionality is introduced.
- Reviews MUST verify that acceptance tests reflect the intended behavior and
  that implementation aligns with the mapped use cases.

## Governance

- This constitution supersedes all other project guidance.
- Amendments require documentation of the rationale, scope, and migration plan
  (if behavior changes or breaking constraints are introduced).
- Semantic versioning applies: MAJOR for breaking governance changes, MINOR for
  new/expanded principles or sections, PATCH for clarifications and wording.
- Compliance is reviewed during planning and before acceptance of changes.

**Version**: 1.0.0 | **Ratified**: 2026-01-31 | **Last Amended**: 2026-01-31

     5	**Status**: Draft  
     6	**Input**: User description: "UC-11.md UC-11-AT.md"
     7	
     8	## User Scenarios & Testing *(mandatory)*
     9	
    10	## Clarifications
    11	
    12	### Session 2026-02-02
    13	
    14	- Q: What should happen to a review invitation after the review due date passes? → A: Automatically becomes declined.
    15	- Q: What level of paper detail should be visible in the invitation list before acceptance? → A: Title only; abstract visible after accepting.
    16	- Q: What error message style should be shown when invitations cannot be retrieved? → A: Generic message with retry guidance (“Try again later or refresh”).
    17	- Q: What invitation statuses should be shown in the default invitations list view? → A: Show only pending by default; allow filtering for others.
    18	- Q: Is login required to view the invitations list? → A: Yes, login required.
    19	
    20	## Scope Clarifications
    21	
    22	- Accept/Reject processing logic is in scope for UC-11; selecting either updates the invitation status.
    23	- Invitation detail view and abstract visibility after acceptance are handled in a separate use case; UC-11 only covers the invitations list view.
    24	- Invitation list ordering (newest first) and pagination (beyond 20 items) are required in this feature.
    25	- Keyboard-only navigation support is required for the invitations list view.
    26	
    27	## Use Case Mapping *(mandatory)*
    28	
    29	- **Primary Use Case(s)**: UC-11
    30	- **Acceptance Tests**: UC-11-AT
    31	- **Notes**: Specifies behavior for receiving and viewing review invitations for assigned papers.
    32	
    33	## Constitution Check
    34	
    35	*GATE: Must pass before implementation.*
    36	
    37	- [x] Use-case traceability: feature maps to `UC-11.md`
    38	- [x] Acceptance tests: `UC-11-AT.md` identified for updates
    39	- [x] MVC separation: model/view/controller boundaries planned
    40	- [x] Vanilla stack: HTML/CSS/JS only; no frameworks or build-tool dependencies
    41	
    42	### User Story 1 - View Pending Review Invitation (Priority: P1)
    43	
    44	As a reviewer, I want to see my pending review invitations so I can decide whether to accept or reject each assignment.
    45	
    46	**Why this priority**: This is the core value of the feature; without it, reviewers cannot respond to review requests.
    47	
    48	**Independent Test**: Can be fully tested by assigning a reviewer to a paper and confirming the invitation appears with Accept/Reject options.
    49	
    50	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    51	
    52	1. **Given** a reviewer is assigned to a paper, **When** the reviewer views their invitations list, **Then** the pending invitation appears with paper title and Accept/Reject options.
    53	2. **Given** a reviewer has multiple pending invitations, **When** they view the invitations list, **Then** each invitation is listed and correctly associated with its paper.
    54	
    55	---
    56	
    57	### User Story 2 - Receive Invitation Notification (Priority: P2)
    58	
    59	As a reviewer, I want to be notified when I receive a new review invitation so I don’t miss review requests.
    60	
    61	**Why this priority**: Notifications reduce missed assignments and improve response time.
    62	
    63	**Independent Test**: Can be tested by creating an invitation and verifying a notification is sent to the reviewer’s registered contact method.
    64	
    65	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    66	
    67	1. **Given** a reviewer is assigned to a paper and notification service is available, **When** the invitation is created, **Then** the reviewer receives a notification of the invitation.
    68	
    69	---
    70	
    71	### User Story 3 - Secure and Resilient Access (Priority: P3)
    72	
    73	As a reviewer, I want my invitations to remain accessible even if notifications fail, and I expect only invited reviewers to see each invitation.
    74	
    75	**Why this priority**: Ensures reliability and protects confidentiality of submissions.
    76	
    77	**Independent Test**: Can be tested by simulating notification failure, delayed login, and unauthorized access attempts while verifying correct visibility and messaging.
    78	
    79	**Acceptance Scenarios**:
    80	
    81	1. **Given** a notification failure occurs, **When** the reviewer later views their invitations, **Then** the invitation is still visible and actionable.
    82	2. **Given** a reviewer who is not invited to a paper, **When** they attempt to access that invitation, **Then** access is denied or the invitation is not shown.
    83	3. **Given** an invitation retrieval error occurs, **When** the reviewer views invitations, **Then** a generic error message with retry guidance is shown.
    84	
    85	---
    86	
    87	### Edge Cases
    88	
    89	- Reviewer does not log in until days after the invitation is created.
    90	- Notification delivery fails but the invitation still exists.
    91	- Multiple invitations for different papers must be distinguishable.
    92	- A system error prevents invitations from loading.
    93	- A reviewer attempts to access an invitation they were not assigned.
    94	- Review due date passes before response.
    95	
    96	## Requirements *(mandatory)*
    97	
    98	### Functional Requirements
    99	
   100	- **FR-001**: System MUST create a review invitation when an editor assigns a reviewer to a paper.
   101	- **FR-002**: System MUST display pending review invitations to the invited reviewer with paper title and invitation status.
   102	- **FR-003**: System MUST provide Accept and Reject options for each pending invitation and persist the reviewer decision.
   103	- **FR-004**: System MUST attempt to send a review invitation notification to the reviewer when an invitation is created.
   104	- **FR-005**: System MUST keep the invitation available in the CMS even if notification delivery fails.
   105	- **FR-006**: System MUST restrict invitation visibility to the invited reviewer.
   106	- **FR-007**: System MUST automatically mark an invitation as declined when the review due date passes without a response.
   107	- **FR-008**: System MUST show a generic, user-friendly error message with retry guidance when invitations cannot be retrieved.
   108	- **FR-009**: System MUST allow reviewers with multiple invitations to view each invitation as a distinct item linked to the correct paper.
   109	- **FR-010**: System MUST limit invitation list details to paper title prior to acceptance.
   110	- **FR-011**: System MUST show only pending invitations by default and allow filtering to view non-pending invitations.
   111	- **FR-012**: System MUST require the reviewer to be logged in to view invitations.
   112	- **FR-013**: System MUST order invitations newest first and support pagination beyond 20 items.
   113	- **FR-014**: System MUST include paper title and response due date in invitation notifications.
   114	
   115	### Assumptions
   116	
   117	- The reviewer’s registered contact method is used for invitation notifications.
   118	
   119	### Key Entities *(include if feature involves data)*
   120	
   121	- **Review Invitation**: Represents a request to review a paper; includes status (pending/accepted/rejected/declined/expired), created date, and response deadline.
   122	- **Reviewer**: Registered user who can view and respond to invitations; includes contact information.
   123	- **Paper**: The submission being reviewed; includes identifier, title, and abstract.
   124	- **Notification**: The outbound message informing a reviewer about a new invitation and its delivery status.
   125	
   126	### Non-Functional Requirements
   127	
   128	- **NFR-001**: Invitation list loads within 2 seconds under normal load.
   129	- **NFR-002**: Invitations are visible to the invited reviewer within 1 minute of assignment.
   130	- **NFR-003**: Invitations list is keyboard accessible (tab order, focus states, and actionable controls usable without a mouse).
   131	
   132	## Success Criteria *(mandatory)*
   133	
   134	### Measurable Outcomes
   135	
   136	- **SC-001**: 95% of reviewers can locate a pending invitation within 2 minutes of logging in during usability testing.
   137	- **SC-002**: 99% of invitations are visible to the invited reviewer within 1 minute of assignment in controlled tests.
   138	- **SC-003**: 98% of invitation notifications are delivered successfully when the notification service is available.
   139	- **SC-004**: 100% of access attempts by non-invited reviewers are blocked in authorization tests.
   140	- **SC-005**: 100% of invitation retrieval failures display a generic message with retry guidance in testing.

   135	- [ ] T036 [P] Validate and update quickstart steps in specs/001-review-invitation/quickstart.md for performance, 1-minute visibility, and keyboard checks
   136	
   137	---
   138	
   139	## Dependencies & Execution Order
   140	
   141	### Phase Dependencies
   142	
   143	- **Setup (Phase 1)**: No dependencies - can start immediately
   144	- **Foundational (Phase 2)**: Depends on Setup completion - BLOCKS all user stories
   145	- **User Stories (Phase 3+)**: All depend on Foundational phase completion
   146	- **Polish (Final Phase)**: Depends on all desired user stories being complete
   147	
   148	### User Story Dependencies
   149	
   150	- **User Story 1 (P1)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - No dependencies on other stories
   151	- **User Story 2 (P2)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - Independent of US1 but uses shared foundation
   152	- **User Story 3 (P3)**: Can start after Foundational (Phase 2) - Independent of US1/US2 but uses shared foundation
   153	
   154	### Within Each User Story
   155	
   156	- Acceptance tests in `UC-11-AT.md` before implementation
   157	- Models before services
   158	- Services before controllers/views
   159	- Core implementation before integration
   160	
   161	### Parallel Opportunities
   162	
   163	- Phase 1 tasks marked [P]
   164	- Phase 2 tasks marked [P]
   165	- Acceptance test updates per user story
   166	- Model creation within a user story
   167	- Different user stories can run in parallel after Phase 2
   168	
   169	---
   170	
   171	## Parallel Example: User Story 1
   172	
   173	```bash
   174	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 1 first:
   175	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for list fields, ordering, pagination, default pending filter, and action buttons"
   176	
   177	# Launch models for User Story 1 together:
   178	Task: "Create ReviewInvitation model in src/models/review_invitation.js"
   179	Task: "Create Paper model in src/models/paper.js"
   180	```
   181	
   182	---
   183	
   184	## Parallel Example: User Story 2
   185	
   186	```bash
   187	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 2 first:
   188	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for notification delivery and content"
   189	
   190	# Run model and template work together:
   191	Task: "Create Notification model in src/models/notification.js"
   192	Task: "Create notification template content in src/views/templates/review-invitation-notification.txt"
   193	```
   194	
   195	---
   196	
   197	## Parallel Example: User Story 3
   198	
   199	```bash
   200	# Update acceptance tests for User Story 3 first:
   201	Task: "Update acceptance tests in UC-11-AT.md for authorization, notification failure resilience, and generic retry messaging"
   202	
   203	# Parallelize auth + logging:
   204	Task: "Enforce reviewer authorization in src/services/authorization_service.js"
   205	Task: "Add audit logging for unauthorized access attempts in src/services/security_log_service.js"
   206	```
   207	
   208	---
   209	
   210	## Implementation Strategy
   211	
   212	### MVP First (User Story 1 Only)
   213	
   214	1. Complete Phase 1: Setup
   215	2. Complete Phase 2: Foundational (CRITICAL - blocks all stories)
   216	3. Complete Phase 3: User Story 1
   217	4. **STOP and VALIDATE**: Test User Story 1 independently
   218	5. Deploy/demo if ready
   219	
   220	### Incremental Delivery
   221	
   222	1. Complete Setup + Foundational → Foundation ready
   223	2. Add User Story 1 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo (MVP!)
   224	3. Add User Story 2 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   225	4. Add User Story 3 → Test independently → Deploy/Demo
   226	5. Each story adds value without breaking previous stories
   227	
   228	### Parallel Team Strategy
   229	
   230	With multiple developers:
   231	
   232	1. Team completes Setup + Foundational together
   233	2. Once Foundational is done:
   234	   - Developer A: User Story 1
   235	   - Developer B: User Story 2
   236	   - Developer C: User Story 3
   237	3. Stories complete and integrate independently
   238	
   239	---
   240	
   241	## Notes
   242	
   243	- [P] tasks = different files, no dependencies
   244	- [Story] label maps task to specific user story for traceability
   245	- Each user story should be independently completable and testable
   246	- Verify acceptance criteria are defined before implementing
   247	- Avoid vague tasks and cross-story dependencies

You **MUST** consider the user input before proceeding (if not empty).

## Goal

Identify inconsistencies, duplications, ambiguities, and underspecified items across the three core artifacts (`spec.md`, `plan.md`, `tasks.md`) before implementation. This command MUST run only after `/speckit.tasks` has successfully produced a complete `tasks.md`.

## Operating Constraints

**STRICTLY READ-ONLY**: Do **not** modify any files. Output a structured analysis report. Offer an optional remediation plan (user must explicitly approve before any follow-up editing commands would be invoked manually).

**Constitution Authority**: The project constitution (`.specify/memory/constitution.md`) is **non-negotiable** within this analysis scope. Constitution conflicts are automatically CRITICAL and require adjustment of the spec, plan, or tasks—not dilution, reinterpretation, or silent ignoring of the principle. If a principle itself needs to change, that must occur in a separate, explicit constitution update outside `/speckit.analyze`.

## Execution Steps

### 1. Initialize Analysis Context

Run `.specify/scripts/bash/check-prerequisites.sh --json --require-tasks --include-tasks` once from repo root and parse JSON for FEATURE_DIR and AVAILABLE_DOCS. Derive absolute paths:

- SPEC = FEATURE_DIR/spec.md
- PLAN = FEATURE_DIR/plan.md
- TASKS = FEATURE_DIR/tasks.md

Abort with an error message if any required file is missing (instruct the user to run missing prerequisite command).
For single quotes in args like "I'm Groot", use escape syntax: e.g 'I'\''m Groot' (or double-quote if possible: "I'm Groot").

### 2. Load Artifacts (Progressive Disclosure)

Load only the minimal necessary context from each artifact:

**From spec.md:**

- Overview/Context
- Functional Requirements
- Non-Functional Requirements
- User Stories
- Edge Cases (if present)

**From plan.md:**

- Architecture/stack choices
- Data Model references
- Phases
- Technical constraints

**From tasks.md:**

- Task IDs
- Descriptions
- Phase grouping
- Parallel markers [P]
- Referenced file paths

**From constitution:**

- Load `.specify/memory/constitution.md` for principle validation

### 3. Build Semantic Models

Create internal representations (do not include raw artifacts in output):

- **Requirements inventory**: Each functional + non-functional requirement with a stable key (derive slug based on imperative phrase; e.g., "User can upload file" → `user-can-upload-file`)
- **User story/action inventory**: Discrete user actions with acceptance criteria
- **Task coverage mapping**: Map each task to one or more requirements or stories (inference by keyword / explicit reference patterns like IDs or key phrases)
- **Constitution rule set**: Extract principle names and MUST/SHOULD normative statements

### 4. Detection Passes (Token-Efficient Analysis)

Focus on high-signal findings. Limit to 50 findings total; aggregate remainder in overflow summary.

#### A. Duplication Detection

- Identify near-duplicate requirements
- Mark lower-quality phrasing for consolidation

#### B. Ambiguity Detection

- Flag vague adjectives (fast, scalable, secure, intuitive, robust) lacking measurable criteria
- Flag unresolved placeholders (TODO, TKTK, ???, `<placeholder>`, etc.)

#### C. Underspecification

- Requirements with verbs but missing object or measurable outcome
- User stories missing acceptance criteria alignment
- Tasks referencing files or components not defined in spec/plan

#### D. Constitution Alignment

- Any requirement or plan element conflicting with a MUST principle
- Missing mandated sections or quality gates from constitution

#### E. Coverage Gaps

- Requirements with zero associated tasks
- Tasks with no mapped requirement/story
- Non-functional requirements not reflected in tasks (e.g., performance, security)

#### F. Inconsistency

- Terminology drift (same concept named differently across files)
- Data entities referenced in plan but absent in spec (or vice versa)
- Task ordering contradictions (e.g., integration tasks before foundational setup tasks without dependency note)
- Conflicting requirements (e.g., one requires Next.js while other specifies Vue)

### 5. Severity Assignment

Use this heuristic to prioritize findings:

- **CRITICAL**: Violates constitution MUST, missing core spec artifact, or requirement with zero coverage that blocks baseline functionality
- **HIGH**: Duplicate or conflicting requirement, ambiguous security/performance attribute, untestable acceptance criterion
- **MEDIUM**: Terminology drift, missing non-functional task coverage, underspecified edge case
- **LOW**: Style/wording improvements, minor redundancy not affecting execution order

### 6. Produce Compact Analysis Report

Output a Markdown report (no file writes) with the following structure:

## Specification Analysis Report

| ID | Category | Severity | Location(s) | Summary | Recommendation |
|----|----------|----------|-------------|---------|----------------|
| A1 | Duplication | HIGH | spec.md:L120-134 | Two similar requirements ... | Merge phrasing; keep clearer version |

(Add one row per finding; generate stable IDs prefixed by category initial.)

**Coverage Summary Table:**

| Requirement Key | Has Task? | Task IDs | Notes |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|-------|

**Constitution Alignment Issues:** (if any)

**Unmapped Tasks:** (if any)

**Metrics:**

- Total Requirements
- Total Tasks
- Coverage % (requirements with >=1 task)
- Ambiguity Count
- Duplication Count
- Critical Issues Count

### 7. Provide Next Actions

At end of report, output a concise Next Actions block:

- If CRITICAL issues exist: Recommend resolving before `/speckit.implement`
- If only LOW/MEDIUM: User may proceed, but provide improvement suggestions
- Provide explicit command suggestions: e.g., "Run /speckit.specify with refinement", "Run /speckit.plan to adjust architecture", "Manually edit tasks.md to add coverage for 'performance-metrics'"

### 8. Offer Remediation

Ask the user: "Would you like me to suggest concrete remediation edits for the top N issues?" (Do NOT apply them automatically.)

## Operating Principles

### Context Efficiency

- **Minimal high-signal tokens**: Focus on actionable findings, not exhaustive documentation
- **Progressive disclosure**: Load artifacts incrementally; don't dump all content into analysis
- **Token-efficient output**: Limit findings table to 50 rows; summarize overflow
- **Deterministic results**: Rerunning without changes should produce consistent IDs and counts

### Analysis Guidelines

- **NEVER modify files** (this is read-only analysis)
- **NEVER hallucinate missing sections** (if absent, report them accurately)
- **Prioritize constitution violations** (these are always CRITICAL)
- **Use examples over exhaustive rules** (cite specific instances, not generic patterns)
- **Report zero issues gracefully** (emit success report with coverage statistics)

# Lab2 CMS Constitution

## Core Principles

### I. Use-Case Traceability (NON-NEGOTIABLE)
Every feature or change MUST map to a specific use case file `UC-XX.md`. If a new
use case is introduced, a new `UC-XX.md` MUST be added and referenced in specs,
plans, and tasks. No implementation is accepted without explicit use-case linkage.

### II. Acceptance Tests as Contract
Acceptance tests are the source of truth and live in `UC-XX-AT.md` files paired
with their use cases. Updates to behavior MUST update the corresponding
acceptance test document before or alongside implementation, and a feature is
only complete when its acceptance criteria are demonstrably satisfied.

### III. MVC Separation
The CMS MUST follow MVC architecture. Models encapsulate data and domain rules,
controllers coordinate user interactions and application flow, and views render
presentation only. Business logic in views is prohibited.

### IV. Vanilla Web Stack Only
Implementation MUST use vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Frameworks, UI
libraries, and build-tool-dependent abstractions are not allowed unless the
constitution is amended to permit them.

### V. Simplicity & Clarity
Prefer the simplest structure that satisfies the use case and acceptance tests.
Avoid unnecessary abstractions or premature generalization; clarity and
readability take precedence over cleverness.

## Project Constraints

- Use cases are stored in `UC-XX.md` and acceptance tests in `UC-XX-AT.md`.
- Any new use case MUST follow the next sequential `UC-XX` identifier and include
  a matching acceptance test file.
- All project documentation (specs, plans, tasks) MUST reference the relevant
  `UC-XX` identifiers for traceability.

## Development Workflow & Quality Gates

- Every plan and spec MUST include a constitution check validating: use-case
  traceability, acceptance test coverage, MVC separation, and vanilla stack
  compliance.
- Tasks MUST include explicit steps to update/add `UC-XX.md` and `UC-XX-AT.md`
  when behavior changes or new functionality is introduced.
- Reviews MUST verify that acceptance tests reflect the intended behavior and
  that implementation aligns with the mapped use cases.

## Governance

- This constitution supersedes all other project guidance.
- Amendments require documentation of the rationale, scope, and migration plan
  (if behavior changes or breaking constraints are introduced).
- Semantic versioning applies: MAJOR for breaking governance changes, MINOR for
  new/expanded principles or sections, PATCH for clarifications and wording.
- Compliance is reviewed during planning and before acceptance of changes.

**Version**: 1.0.0 | **Ratified**: 2026-01-31 | **Last Amended**: 2026-01-31
